item.title: Musk Confidant Leaves Tesla in Latest Executive Departure
item.description: A Tesla executive and key confidant to CEO Elon Musk, Omead Afshar, has left the company, according to people familiar with the matter. This latest high-level departure comes during a volatile period for the electric vehicle maker. Ed Ludlow and Caroline Hyde discuss this latest development on “Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: South Korea Prices €1.4 Billion Euro Bond Amid Strong Demand
item.description: South Korea priced €1.4 billion of euro-denominated bonds on Thursday, drawing robust investor demand as it returned to the euro debt market after a gap of nearly four years.
item.dc:creator: Haram Lim

media:content.media:description: The National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, April 7, 2025. South Korea has set June 3 as the tentative date for the next presidential election, Yonhap News reported on Monday, citing an unidentified government official.

item.title: When Should We Care About Unrealized Bank Losses?
item.description: What really happened in 2023?
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Signage at a Silicon Valley Bank branch in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, March 13, 2023. The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank has prompted a global reckoning at venture capital and private equity firms, which found themselves suddenly exposed all together to the tech industry's money machine. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Platinum Jumps to Highest Since 2014 on Mounting Supply Concerns
item.description: Platinum climbed to the highest level since 2014 as supply concerns and a wave of speculative buying led by the US and China jolted the market.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan, Elise Harris, Yihui Xie

item.title: Oil Tanker Rates Collapse as Conflict in Middle East Abates
item.description: The cost of shipping Middle East crude to customers in Asia collapsed on Thursday, the latest sign of oil markets returning to normal after conflict eased in the world’s top petroleum-exporting region.
item.dc:creator: Erik Olsson

item.title: S&P 500 Just a Few Points Away From Record Close: Markets Wrap
item.description: A mixed batch of economic data failed to stop the S&P 500 from pushing within a striking distance of a record high, with Treasury yields falling alongside the dollar amid growing bets on Federal Reserve rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: UK Fintech Giant Revolut to Acquire BNP’s Cetelem in Argentina
item.description: Revolut Ltd., Europe’s largest digital bank, is acquiring Argentina’s Banco Cetelem, a small local lender owned by BNP Paribas, according to two people with direct knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll, Aisha S Gani

media:content.media:description: London-based fintech Revolut, recently valued at about $45 billion, has some 60 million customers worldwide. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Copper Spreads Spike Again as Goldman Says Shortages to Worsen
item.description: A key one-day copper price spread surged to the highest level in four years on the London Metal Exchange, placing fresh strains on buyers contending with a rapid decline in inventories.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Charlie Zhu, Winnie Zhu

media:content.media:description: Copper rods at a wholesale metal dealer in Mumbai, India.

item.title: S&P 500 Homes In on Record as Trump Posits Powell Replacement
item.description: US stocks resumed their climb Thursday with the S&P 500 Index narrowing in on a record following a report President Donald Trump will announce his pick for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s replacement earlier than anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: Fed Will Cut if Labor Market Weakens: Renaud-Chatelain
item.description: Laureline Renaud-Chatelain, Senior Fixed Income Strategist at Pictet Wealth Management, discusses the possibility of a 'shadow' Fed Chair, issuance at the short-end of the curve and whether bond markets will be concerned over increased NATO spending. She speaks to Bloomberg's Anna Edwards, Kriti Gupta and Guy Johnson on 'Opening Trade.' (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Advances on Conflicting Signs About Iran’s Nuclear Program
item.description: Oil advanced on conflicting signals about how much US military strikes hobbled Iran’s nuclear program and whether Washington will continue to target Tehran’s oil flows.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

item.title: China Imports Argentina Soy Meal in Trial Amid US Tensions
item.description: China has booked a rare shipment of soybean meal from Argentina, as the country seeks to secure supplies of a key animal feed ingredient amid an ongoing trade war with the US.
item.dc:creator: Alfred Cang, Hallie Gu

media:content.media:description: A tractor moves soybean meal at a Molinos Agro soybean processing and crushing facility in Rosario, Santa Fe province, Argentina, on Tuesday, March 26, 2024. The vast amounts of soybeans set to be crushed for its oil - a key feedstock in making renewable diesel - will create piles of co-product meal in the US, posing a threat to Argentina's biggest export.

item.title: What Jefferies Profit Slump Signals for Bank Stocks
item.description: Jefferies Financial Group’s second-quarter earnings declined on a slump in the firm’s investment-banking and capital-markets businesses. Katherine Doherty has more on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: Germany’s Largest Gas Storage Still Empty Amid Fill Effort
item.description: Germany’s largest gas storage facility failed to allocate capacity at its latest auction, raising risks that the country will struggle to meet legally binding stockpiling targets ahead of winter.
item.dc:creator: Carolynn Look

media:content.media:description: The natural gas storage facility operated by Astora GmbH & Co KG, one of the largest in Western Europe and formerly controlled by Gazprom Germania GmbH, in Rehden, Germany, on Tuesday, Aug. 23, 2022. Astora, a former unit of Gazprom Germania GmbH now named SEFE Securing Energy for Europe GmbH, is seeking relief from a levy to share the burden of higher gas prices with consumers, according to a person familiar with the situation.

item.title: Wall Street Goes All-In on Risky Stocks
item.description: Investors are piling into speculative and volatile edges of the stock market, throwing caution to the wind as the S&P 500 Index closes in on a new all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey, Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Jefferson Capital Rises 27% After Bottom-Priced $150 Million IPO
item.description: Jefferson Capital Inc. shares rose as much as 27% in its public debut after the company and some of its backers raised $150 million in an initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Georgie McKay, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Tuesday, April 22, 2025. US stocks pared gains as traders weighed earlier remarks from Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent on the US-China tariff standoff. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Informal Mining Boom Is Biggest Fear for Peru’s Copper Investors
item.description: The biggest threat to Peru tapping more of its giant copper deposits is rising informal and illegal mining activity, according to the head of the country’s main industry association, SNMPE.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

media:content.media:description: An employee sprays anti-oxidant solution on a pile of copper plates at a refinery in Ilo, Peru.

item.title: Bloomberg Surveillance 6/26/2025
item.description: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Impossible Foods CEO on European Expansion Strategy
item.description: Peter McGuinness, President & CEO, Impossible Foods discusses the company’s European expansion and evolving business strategy with Bloomberg's Kriti Gupta at the Bloomberg Sustainable Business Summit 2025 in London. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Inter Milan Places €350 Million New Private Debt to Repay Bonds
item.description: FC Internazionale Milano SpA has placed €350 million ($410 million) of private debt with institutional investors, granting it the funds to repay current bondholders.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Lautaro Martinez of FC Internazionale Milano celebrates after scoring a goal during a match at Lumen Field in Seattle, on June 21.

item.title: Anushka Gupta on Investing for Family Office Clients
item.description: Anushka Gupta, Americas Head of Goldman Sachs Apex, talks about investing with a global perspective. (This interview occurred on June 18) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump’s Crypto Project Gets $100 Million From UAE-Based Fund
item.description: A little known crypto fund bought $100 million of World Liberty Financial Inc. tokens, the second Middle East-based investor to put money into the Trump family affiliated decentralized finance platform.
item.dc:creator: Muyao Shen

item.title: Next-Gen CSOs: Evolving Sustainability Roles
item.description: Chief Sustainability Officers Claudine Blamey (Aviva), Alex Buck (Endeavour Mining), and Charlotte Wolff-Bye (PETRONAS) discuss the evolving roles and skills of Chief Sustainability Officers with Bloomberg's Yinka Ibukun at the Bloomberg Sustainable Business Summit 2025 in London. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Insurance in the Era of Climate Change
item.description: Irene Heemskerk, Head, Climate Change Centre, European Central Bank; Ekhosuehi Iyahen, Secretary General, Insurance Development Forum; and Nicolas Jeanmart, Head, Personal & General Insurance, Insurance Europe discuss the challenges and opportunities facing insurers in the era of climate change with Bloomberg's Gautam Naik at the Bloomberg Sustainable Business Summit 2025 in London. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed Being on Hold Is Bolstering Markets, Schwab's Sonders Says
item.description: "Cutting rates here isn't really the elixir" for markets, Charles Schwab Chief Investment Strategist Liz Ann Sonders says on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: National Wealth Fund & Barclays on Transition Finance
item.description: John Flint, CEO of the National Wealth Fund and Daniel Hanna, Group Head of Sustainable & Transition Finance at Barclays discuss the need for public-private partnerships to accelerate the energy transition with Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua at the Bloomberg Sustainable Business Summit 2025 in London. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Circle K Owner Sees Clarity on Seven & I Deal Sooner Than Later
item.description: Circle K owner Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. slightly missed earnings estimates and said it’s expecting resolution in its deal talks with Seven & i Holdings Co. fairly soon.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: A Circle K convenience store at a gas station in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024. Circle K operator Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. made a proposal to take over much larger rival and 7-Eleven owner Seven & i Holdings Co., in what would be the biggest foreign takeover of a Japanese company. Photographer: Laura Proctor/Bloomberg

item.title: US Pending Home-Sales Pick Up in May, With Gains Across Regions
item.description: Pending sales of previously owned homes in the US picked up in May after a sharp decline a month earlier, although overall activity remained subdued headed into summer.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: A house under contract in Pasadena, California.

item.title: It's 'Game On' for Bank Stocks as Rules Relax and Deals Rebound, Mayo Says
item.description: Loosening regulations, the steady drumbeat of dealmaking, elevated interest rates: It’s a recipe for US banking stocks shares to keep ripping higher.
item.dc:creator: Georgie McKay

item.title: US Merchandise-Trade Deficit Unexpectedly Widens on Exports Drop
item.description: The US merchandise-trade deficit unexpectedly widened in May on the biggest drop in exports since the onset of the pandemic, while imports were little changed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: The shortfall in goods trade grew 11.1% to $96.6 billion, Commerce Department data showed. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg
